awd_titl_txt: Nonlinear Optical and Simulation Studies of Perturbed Liquids
awd_abstract_narration:
In this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms (CSDM-A) Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor John Fourkas of the University of Maryland College Park and his graduate student researchers are doing experimental and computational studies to probe the dynamics of molecular liquids in nano-confinement and under negative pressure.  Despite the importance of liquids as solvents in important chemical processes, there is a great deal that is still unknown about liquid behavior in confined and other unusual environments being studied in the present work.  Graduate students working on this project receive excellent training in experimental physical chemistry.  This project benefits from the collaboration with Dr. Benoit Coasne, a computational chemist at CNRS (France) and MIT.

Prof. Fourkas and his research group are conducting a series of experimental and modeling studies of the behavior of molecular liquids in nano-confined environments and under tension.  The experiments to be carried out include:  (1) optical Kerr effect (OKE) spectroscopy and (2) vibrational sum-frequency generation (VSFG) spectroscopy.  The Fourkas group researchers will use these methods to probe the local liquid density via the reduced spectral density. Liquids will be confined in nanoporous silica and stretched liquids will be prepared in Berthelot tubes.  Liquids to be studied include benzene, pyridine, acetonitrile and 2-butene.  Liquids in environments like those studied here are ubiquitous, but remain poorly understood, and work like that supported in this study will help to shed light on the molecular behavior that governs the liquid behavior.  Students working on this project receive excellent training in chemical physics that prepares them to become globally-engaged members of the technical workforce.

por.por_cntn:
A surface can change the way that a liquid behaves. For instance, water can spread into a thin sheet on some surfaces, but beads up on others. When a liquid is confined inside a region that is a few molecules across (nanoconfinement), the behavior of the liquid can change even more radically. Understanding how surfaces and nanoconfinement affect liquids is important for chemists who wish to devise new ways to catalyze chemical reactions or separate different chemicals from one another. Such an understanding could help to improve a wide range of technological applications, such as lubrication and oil recovery. The research performed under this grant used laser-based experiments and computer simulations to gain new insights into a number of aspects of liquids at surfaces and in nanoconfinement that are of direct relevance to important applications.

 

Acetonitrile is a liquid that is widely used as a solvent for both chemical reactions and chemical separations. A laser-based technique called vibrational sum-frequency generation (VSFG) allows us to focus in on these molecules closest a glass surface, even though there is a vastly greater number of molecules in the rest of the liquid. Our previous VSFG work has showed that molecules of acetonitrile organize in an unexpected manner at a glass surface: one layer of molecules stands up from the surface pointing in one direction, and then a second layer points in the opposite direction. This organization persists even in the presence of water, which explains for the first time how an important separation technique called hydrophilic interaction chromatography (HILIC) works so effectively. In this project we used VSFG to study how HILIC might be improved further, including varying temperature and adding molecules that could drive the organization of acetonitrile that is responsible for efficient separations. At the same time, we showed that molecular phenomena that are not usually considered can have an important influence on VSFG spectroscopy. Our work increases the information content available from this technique, which will be of value in a broad range of studies of phenomena at interfaces.

 

Acetonitrile is also one of a handful of common organic solvents in which many salts are highly soluble. Lithium salts, in particular, are of great interest for battery applications. We have used VSFG to study where the positively charged lithium ions and their negatively charged partners are positioned at the interface between acetonitrile and glass. Remarkably, the organization of acetonitrile at this interfaces persists up to high salt concentrations. This work will require scientists to rethink our understanding of the organization of ions at interfaces.

 

An important property that determines how a liquid behaves is its density, i.e. how many molecules can fit in a particular volume. When the volume of the contained in which the liquid is held is large, the concept of density is well defined. However, the situation is different when the size of the container is not much greater than the size of the molecules within it. In this case, it becomes difficult to determine the volume available to the liquid. Imagine, for instance, measuring the volume of a coffee cup using water. A tennis ball placed in an identical coffee cup would not experience the same volume that the water does. This is a longstanding problem in the study of nanoconfined liquids, and it has resisted attempts to solve it either with experiments or simulations. We have used a laser-based technique called optical Kerr effect spectroscopy, along with computer simulations, to show that the “intrinsic” density of a nanoconfined liquid can be determined by monitoring the motions of the liquid molecules. Our approach is revolutionary, and is compatible with a range of different experimental techniques. The ability to determine the density of nanoconfined liquids has the potential for widespread applications, including improved catalysts, development of selective membranes for filtration, and enhanced oil recovery techniques.
